David Brady wrote:
> We use a bunch of static methods on various classes to provide
> functionality.  Today I realized I have no idea how to mock these
> classes.  Objects yes, classes no.
> 
> Is there a good refactoring to fix this?
> 
> Example:
> 
> public class DbAccess {
>     public static ResultSet query(DbQuery query) {
>         // ...creates the necessary Db objects and returns a ResultSet
> object.
>     }
> }
> 
> If I want to mock the database access, I'm going to need to either swap
> DbAccess to DbAccessMock, or I'll need DbAccess.query() to redirect
> through an interceptable (mockable) interface.
> 
> Is there a standard refactoring for this?

One option is to add an overloaded version of the method that takes as 
parameters all the object you need to substitute. If there's only 1 such 
method, this is a good option.

Another option is to move the class-level method onto a new class, into 
which you can inject dependencies through the constructor. If there are 
many such methods, this is a better option. (It's a specific case of the 
more general refactoring: move related class-level methods to a new class.)

I hope that helps.
